Radcliffe Named as New Board of Trustees Chairman
George C. Radcliffe has been
elected Chairman of Hopkins'
Board of Trustees, succeeding
Robert D.H. Harvey, who
retired April 16 after 16 years
as Chairman.

Notice to
Our Readers
This is the last News-Letter
of the semester. Publication
will resume in September.
We'd like to thank those of
you who assisted us throughout the semester. To those of
you who didn't: ha, ha, we
made it anyway.
Bye-bye.

Radcliffe is Chairman of the
Board and President of the
Baltimore Life Insurance Company, and has been a Hopkins
trustee since 1975. He is also a
trustee of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital Endowment Fund,
Inc.
Harvey is Chairman of the
Board of the Maryland National Bank and has been a
trustee of Hopkins since 1959.
University President Steven
Muller said, "Johns Hopkins
University has indeed been
privileged to have Bob Harvey
as chairman. He has seen the
University through a period of
enormous growth and change.
During his tenure, the
program
undergraduate
became coeducational, the

University marked its onehundredth birthday—capped

plant was expanded considerably, the University affiliated with the Peabody Institute, the G.W.C. Whiting
School of Engineering was
opened and the opening of the
School of Nursing announced.
"George Radcliffe is a man
of abiding principles and deep
devotion to his alma mater. I
look forward, as do all the
members of the Board, to
working closely with him as the
University implements exciting
new plans to assure our continuing leadership in higher
education and research. George
Radcliffe comes to the chair-

manship with nine years of
deep involvement with the
board, so he is intimately
familiar with the challenges and
opportunities facing the
University."

Baltimore and graduated from
Baltimore City College in 1941.

interrupted by three years of

The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation
has awarded two of its 283 1984
Fellowships to Hopkins faculty members Stephen Dixon of
the Writing Seminars department and Dr. John Higham of
the History department.
The committee of selection
for the foundation chose

scholars who demonstrated accomplishment in the past and

The Guggenheim Memorial
foundation has granted over

operation.

175 published short stories with
a new collection coming out in

theme of the recent collection

will begin in July, touring for

spend a month in the Soviet
Union. After these two months
of travel, he will return to New
York to continue writing until
the following July when he
returns to Johns Hopkins.

Two Johns Hopkins University faculty members recently
received fellowships from the
prestigious American Academy
in Rome.
The post-graduate fellowhips
were awarded to Herbert L.
Kessler, professor and chairman of the History of Art
department, and David St.
John, assistant professor in
Writing Seminars.
Kessler will research the pictorial narrative paintings in the
early Christian churches of
Rome. The fellowship runs
from September 1984 to August
1985.
A specialist in early Christian
and Western medieval art,
Kessler joined the Hopkins
faculty in 1979. He was formerly professor and University
director of Fine Art at the

University of Chicago, where
he had been a member of the
faculty for 11 years. Prior to
that, he was associated for two
years with the Byzantine Institute of America.
American poet David St.
John • expects to complete a
volume of poetry during his
sabbatical year at the Academy.
His first book of poetry,
Hush, won the Great Lake Colleges' Association New Writers
Award in 1976. Another
volume, The Shore, was
published in 1980. He has also
contributed to several poetry
anthologies and his poems appear frequently in "The New
Yorker," as well as other
magazines,
including
"Poetry", "Antaeus", "The
Paris Review", and "The
Nation."

On a hot August day in 1980,
We first met Lois Van Norman, a middle-aged lady.
That day, as freshmen, true to form,
the Class of '84 moved into the old and new dorms.
We were quite a special bunch,
for the most part normal; a few out to lunch.
Our student advisors offered tons of information,
followed by the excitement of orientation.
Those first few days were relatively easy,
although there were some experiences that were rather sleazy.
For instance, I remember thinking I had diphtheria,
in fact it was a reaction to the freshman cafeteria.
But soon the time ran out for fun,
'cause that next week classes had begun.
That involved finding private study nooks,
and paying exorbitant sums for text books.
That first year some teachers were really grand,
at least the ones we could understand.
If I could have had just one tiny wish,
it'd have been that all my T.A.'s spoke English.
As winter blossomed into spring,
we all began to do our thing.
End of the year excitement reached an unusual height,
when people chose to end it with a giant mud fight.
As sophomores we met a species called "professors",
fairly knowledgeable, though not very good dressers.
In labs and seminars, our minds they did train
although sometimes the volume of work could drive you insane.
Of course there was time for outside activity,
for which people showed unusual proclivity.
There were lots of clubs and teams from which to choose,
so long as meetings didn't interfere with "Hill Street Blues."
With the Student Council I got involved,
as president I saw many problems that got solved.
My Council work not too much would impede,
but at the end of junior year I was treed.
Then I was offered a position that made me blush,
working in the office of Dean Lucien Brush.
To see the deans in Merryman Hall,
is quite an experience, I'm telling y'all.
Soon many of us were studying for LSATs,
and many more were getting ready for those MCATs.
Still others hoped for jobs paying lots of money,
hoping to make the future bright and sunny.
Hopkins provided an opportunity to grow,
and some grew fast, others slow.
Each of us will remember JHU in a personal way,
and with us, certain memories will always stay.
We first became a class during Orientation,
and we come together again for graduation.
Let's make these last days special and warm,
just like those first days in the dorms.
On Hopkins our class leaves its mark,
in Gilman, Shaffer, and Dunning Park.
As for me, I'd like to say to you:
best of luck in all you do.

PET Scanner/Cyclotron Installed at Hospital
The Johns Hopkins Medical
Institutions recently dedicated
two new facilities equipped with
machines for viewing the
brain—the neuroradiology patient facilities and the PET
scanner/cyclotron equipment.
The new award-winning
neuroradiology designs bridge
the gap between high
technology and patient care,
and are incorporated in the
Russell H. Morgan Department
of Radiology and Radiological
Science. The equipment, valued
at more than $10 million, was
designed over a three-year
period for The Johns Hopkins
Hospital, and is now available
nationally.
Certain rooms have special
air circulation and anesthesia
systems, so that surgical profrom
cedures, ranging
stereotactic biopsies to chemical
treatment of degenerating discs,
can be conducted in the same
room with the imaging
equipment.

The PET scanner has been
used in human studies of brain
neurotransmitters, chemicals
that permit communication between nerves. The first successful imaging in humans of a
neurotransmitter receptor, the
dopamine receptor, was performed in the living brain at
Hopkins, using a PET scanner,
in May 1983.
Since then, studies of
seratonin as well as dopamine
receptors have been carried out
in 75 people, 35 normals and 40
patients with various disorders
such as Alzheimer's disease,
Parkinson's disease, and
schizophrenia. The most important finding to date is a 50
percent decrease in the
dopamine and seratonin receptor activity in normal men, but
not women, between 20 and 70
years old. Decreases in receptor
activity have been associated
with some disorders, and the
current area of interest is to
learn why receptor activity differs in men and women.

The new fluoroscopy facility
in the neurosurgery operating
rooms offers surgeons and
radiologists immediate images
during operations instead of the
delayed images of standard Xrays. The cerebral angiography
equipment, for viewing blood
vessels in the brain after an Xray "dye"(contrast medium)is
injected, uses high fidelity disc
and tape technology to review
images without exposing patients to additional radiation.
Leaded, clear acrylic shields,
made-to-order, permit personnel to remain safely with the patient during diagnostic or treatment procedures. Even
angiographic examining tables
have been redesigned for increased patient comfort.
The PET scanner is served by
a 23-ton cyclotron, which
creates the radioactive isotopes
that "label" or mark the
biochemicals to be studied in
the brain. Together, the PET
and cyclotron cost over $2
million.

One of the things that has
fascinated—and
always
perhaps annoyed—followers of
Thomas Pynchon is his persistence in leading a reclusive,
isolated life. For years, he has
refused to grant interviews, to
be photographed, or to give
readings or talks. In fact, few
people even know where he
lives. It is rumored that his
home is in California or Mexico, but almost no one knows
of him except through his three
published novels—V (1963),
The Crying of Lot 49 (1966),
and Gravity's Rainbow (winner
of the National Book Award in
1973).
Now, taking advantage of
Pynchon's associal nature, Little, Brown has published Slow
Learner, a compilation of five
of his early short stories which
appeared in various journals
from 1959-1964, plus a new introduction by the author. It is
this introduction which has called attention to this book. If it
were written by almost anyone
other than Pynchon, Slow
Learner probably wouldn't
have been published; the stories
are,
on
the
whole,
unremarkable. But because of
the intense clampdown Pyn-

chon maintains on his private
life, his followers have grown
anxious to learn more about
him. There have been
numerous studies of his work,
and even a few character sketches of him, but personal insight remains as lean as ever.
It is no surprise then, that the
publishers of Slow Learner
choose to make more noise
about the introduction than
about the pages which follow:
"...I now pretend to have reached a
level of clarity about the young writer
I was back then," Pynchon writes in a
disarming and candid introduction. Indeed, as he proceeds to describe the
genesis of the stories, evoke the cultural
idiosyncrasies that attended them, and
take stock of each one's strengths and
frailties, he reveals more about himself
as a writer—young and old—than his
decoders would have dared hope.

PET Scanner/Cyclotron Installed at Hospital
The Johns Hopkins Medical
Institutions recently dedicated
two new facilities equipped with
machines for viewing the
brain—the neuroradiology patient facilities and the PET
scanner/cyclotron equipment.
The new award-winning
neuroradiology designs bridge
the gap between high
technology and patient care,
and are incorporated in the
Russell H. Morgan Department
of Radiology and Radiological
Science. The equipment, valued
at more than $10 million, was
designed over a three-year
period for The Johns Hopkins
Hospital, and is now available
nationally.
Certain rooms have special
air circulation and anesthesia
systems, so that surgical profrom
cedures, ranging
stereotactic biopsies to chemical
treatment of degenerating discs,
can be conducted in the same
room with the imaging
equipment.

The PET scanner has been
used in human studies of brain
neurotransmitters, chemicals
that permit communication between nerves. The first successful imaging in humans of a
neurotransmitter receptor, the
dopamine receptor, was performed in the living brain at
Hopkins, using a PET scanner,
in May 1983.
Since then, studies of
seratonin as well as dopamine
receptors have been carried out
in 75 people, 35 normals and 40
patients with various disorders
such as Alzheimer's disease,
Parkinson's disease, and
schizophrenia. The most important finding to date is a 50
percent decrease in the
dopamine and seratonin receptor activity in normal men, but
not women, between 20 and 70
years old. Decreases in receptor
activity have been associated
with some disorders, and the
current area of interest is to
learn why receptor activity differs in men and women.

The new fluoroscopy facility
in the neurosurgery operating
rooms offers surgeons and
radiologists immediate images
during operations instead of the
delayed images of standard Xrays. The cerebral angiography
equipment, for viewing blood
vessels in the brain after an Xray "dye"(contrast medium)is
injected, uses high fidelity disc
and tape technology to review
images without exposing patients to additional radiation.
Leaded, clear acrylic shields,
made-to-order, permit personnel to remain safely with the patient during diagnostic or treatment procedures. Even
angiographic examining tables
have been redesigned for increased patient comfort.
The PET scanner is served by
a 23-ton cyclotron, which
creates the radioactive isotopes
that "label" or mark the
biochemicals to be studied in
the brain. Together, the PET
and cyclotron cost over $2
million.
